
In another set of the series of my thoughts on teaching R, I wanted to note some of the jargon that I use when talking about R.

Many of these are for beginners in R and don't correspond to the true R reference, e.g. slots mean something specific in S4 objects in R, I use them interchangeably with element or index.  Many of these are general programming jargon, but I know some users who've never used another programming language so I'll say these are R jargon.

```{r}
jargon = c("code", "code chunk", 
           "script", ".R file", 
           "package", "library", 
           "bang", "not", "not equal", "negate",
           "object", "variable", 
           "element", "slot", "index",
           "indices",
           "column", 
           "CSV", "Comma Separated file", "Comma Separated file", "Excel file",
           "Rda", "R data file", 
           "load", "read in data",
           "argument", "parameter", "option", "passing in", "inputs",
           "console", "command line",
           "script editor", "editor",
           "device", 
           "coercion", 
           "wraparound",
           "nonconformable",
           "workspace", "in memory",
           "session",
           "working directory", "wd",
           "execute", "run",
           "knitr", "knit", "weave", "Sweave",
           "method",
           "attribute", "metadata",
           "equals equals",
           "OR", "pipe", "|", "logical OR",
           "AND", "logical AND", "Ampersand", "&",
           "complete cases", "complete.cases", "nonmissing data",
           "covariates", "independent predictors", "predictors", "regresssors",
           "in", "percent in percent", "%in%"
           )

meaning = c(rep("Any R function or command ", 2),
           "script", ".R file", 
           "package", "library", 
           "bang", "not", "not equal", "negate",
           "object", "variable", 
           "element", "slot", "index",
           "indices",
           "column",
```
